entry.content:
This behavior is usually caused by missing configuration or authorization.
Please double‚Äëcheck that:

  • The business rule is correctly assigned in the Save Rules section of the MDF object

  • The cust_subjectUser field is populated during candidate data collection

  • The Attachment Field Configuration is maintained for each attachment field

  • The admin user has permissions for Onboarding Dashboard ‚Üí Documents

Also confirm the known limitations and prerequisites described in SAP Notes 3192196 and 3203679, as missing one step can result in documents not appearing on the dashboard even though they exist in Manage Documents.

entry.title: Re: Report RSBCS_REORG and KPRO ?
entry.content: ‚Äú‚ÄòDeleted from KPRO‚Äô refers to the physical deletion of SAPoffice document content stored in the Knowledge Provider (KPRO) repositories (e.g. attachments, binary content). ‚ÄòDeleted Address References‚Äô indicates cleanup of obsolete SAPoffice recipient/address entries (e.g. user, distribution list references) linked to the deleted documents. Both are standard housekeeping actions performed by RSBCS_REORG to keep SAPoffice and workflow data consistent.‚Äù

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG still does not delete anything
entry.content: RSBCS_REORG will not delete SAPoffice documents that are still referenced (e.g. in folders, workflows, or via KPRO). Please check: ‚Ä¢ Documents are not in private/shared folders (SOOD/SOOS) ‚Ä¢ No active references in workflows or business objects ‚Ä¢ Retention time parameters and authorization ‚Ä¢ Run SOST / workflow cleanup reports first SAP Notes on SAPoffice reorganization also explain these limitations.

entry.title: Re: RSBCS_REORG report spending much time over SOOD table
entry.content:
RSBCS_REORG performance issues on SOOD are usually caused by very large data volume and inefficient access paths chosen by the DB optimizer. Even with good stats and indexes, deleting very small date ranges (e.g. 1 day) can force index usage and lead to slow row-by-row deletes.

Recommendations:
‚Ä¢ Run RSBCS_REORG in larger date ranges (weekly/monthly) instead of daily
‚Ä¢ Execute during low system load and consider background jobs with smaller packages
‚Ä¢ Check if KPRO / content server documents are involved, as this increases runtime
‚Ä¢ On some DBs, disabling indexes temporarily or using DB-specific delete optimizations helps
‚Ä¢ Ensure related cleanup reports (RSBCS_REORG_DEL, RSSO_DELETE_*) are executed in correct sequence

This behavior is known for SAPoffice tables (SOOD/SOOS/SOC3) with many years of data.

entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Hi, 

As per understanding your question,

RM from international vendor > sent to External Manufacturer via Plant 1025 (CC1106) > FG received directly at Plant 1800 (CC1100):

  1. Create PO for Raw Material (International Vendor)

ME21N: PO with Plant = 1025, storage location as per process, Incoterms, etc.

  1. Post Import Goods Receipt of Raw Material at Plant 1025

MIGO (GR for PO): Post GR to 1025 (stock available for issue to subcontractor).

  1. Create Subcontracting / External Processing PO for Finished Goods

ME21N: PO to External Manufacturer (Subcontractor)

Item: Finished Good material with Item Category = L (Subcontracting)

Maintain Component list (raw materials/packing if applicable) in PO (or via BOM).

  1. Create Delivery / Issue Components to Subcontractor from Plant 1025

MIGO: Transfer Posting O (Issue components to subcontractor) Stock moves from Plant 1025 to Subcontractor stock (Special stock O)

  1. Subcontractor Manufactures Finished Goods

Physical manufacturing happens at vendor site (no SAP production order needed unless you use advanced integration).

Post Subcontracting Goods Receipt of Finished Goods directly into Plant 1800

  1. MIGO (GR for Subcontracting PO) with Plant = 1800  Receive FG directly into Plant 1800 stock, and system consumes components from vendor stock automatically (based on consumption quantity).

Invoice Verification

  1. MIRO: Post vendor invoice (service/processing charges + any agreed components variance handling).
  2. Stock / Account Verification

Check stock and movements:

MB51 / ME2L, ME23N History, MMBE for stock.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Question: Delivery-cost condition error during Servic...
entry.content:
Delivery cost conditions are primarily designed for logistics processes involving goods receipt, freight, and transportation costs. In material POs, these conditions integrate naturally with GR and invoice verification. However, in service POs, the system processes costs differently because there is no physical delivery or freight component. This mismatch can sometimes trigger errors during Service Entry Sheet (SES) creation if the pricing procedure still expects delivery-related conditions.

Even if the condition is manual and has no records, the system may still treat it as relevant during SES processing if the condition type is flagged as mandatory in the pricing schema, the calculation schema is applied uniformly to both material and service POs without differentiation and the condition category is set in a way that makes it applicable to services, which can cause validation checks during SES posting.

SAP generally expects delivery cost conditions to be excluded from service scenarios, since services do not involve freight or delivery. If the same PO document type and pricing schema are used for both materials and services, the system cannot distinguish automatically. This is why configuration adjustments are often required.

To fix this

  • Use different calculation schemas for material vs. service POs, excluding delivery cost conditions from the service schema.
  • Review the condition type in transaction M/06 and ensure it is not marked as mandatory for service-related schemas.
  • Check schema determination rules (via M/08) to ensure service POs do not inherit delivery cost conditions unnecessarily.
  • Sometimes, conditions behave differently depending on account assignment. Verify if the SES error is linked to account assignment validation.

entry.title: Re: FREIGHT COST (Planned Delivery costs)
entry.content:
Why the issue occurs is because, planned Delivery Costs in SAP are tied to the PO header and linked to a single freight vendor. When you post partial goods receipts, the system distributes the planned delivery costs proportionally. At invoice posting (MIRO), SAP expects the invoicing party to match the freight vendor defined in the PO. If a different freight vendor is used for subsequent deliveries, the system throws the ‚ÄúInvoicing Party is different‚Äù error because the PO does not allow multiple freight vendors for planned delivery costs.

Below are the SAP Best Practices for International Procurement

Use Unplanned Delivery Costs
Instead of fixing freight vendor and costs at PO level, post freight invoices as unplanned delivery costs during MIRO. This allows you to enter different freight vendors and amounts per invoice without PO dependency. The costs are distributed to the PO items automatically.

Separate Freight POs (Service POs)
Create a service PO for freight services per shipment. Each freight forwarder is represented as a separate PO with its own vendor. This keeps the material PO clean and allows flexibility in handling multiple freight vendors.

Use Condition Types for Freight (Delivery Costs)
Configure freight condition types as non‚Äëmandatory and allow manual entry at invoice level. This way, you can adjust freight charges per delivery without system errors.

Split Invoices by Vendor
Post material supplier invoices separately from freight supplier invoices. Each freight invoice can be posted against the PO with unplanned delivery costs or against a dedicated freight PO.

entry.title: Re: Raw material from international vendor to Finished go...
entry.content:
Here is a different way to structure the same business requirement in SAP ECC, using an alternative but still standard approach. You can model the flow with stock transfers and cross‚Äëcompany processes. This gives you more control over valuation and accounting between company codes.

Raw Material Procurement (International Vendor ‚Üí Plant 1025, CC1106)
ME21N: Create a standard PO for raw materials with plant = 1025.
MIGO: Post GR into plant 1025. Raw materials are now available in CC1106.

2. Transfer Raw Materials to Subcontractor
ME21N: Create a stock transport order (STO) or use subcontracting PO depending on setup.
MIGO: Issue raw materials to subcontractor (movement type 541).
Stock moves into special stock O at subcontractor, still owned by plant 1025.

3. Finished Goods Receipt into Plant 1025 (Optional Step)
If you want to keep the subcontracting cycle consistent, you can first post the finished goods receipt back into plant 1025 (movement type 101 for subcontracting PO). This consumes the raw materials from subcontractor stock and creates FG stock in plant 1025.

4. Cross‚ÄëCompany Stock Transfer (Plant 1025 ‚Üí Plant 1800)
ME21N: Create a stock transport order between plant 1025 (CC1106) and plant 1800 (CC1100).
VL10B / VL10D: Create outbound delivery from plant 1025.
VL02N: Post goods issue (movement type 351).
MIGO: Post goods receipt in plant 1800 (movement type 101).

This ensures proper intercompany billing between CC1106 and CC1100 if required.

5. Invoice Verification
MIRO: Post invoice for the subcontractor (processing charges).
Intercompany Billing: If STO is intercompany, create billing document in SD (VF01) and post invoice to CC1100.

This ensures correct financial postings between company codes.

entry.title: Re: MRP-RUN : STR ( stock transfer requisition) cansidred...
entry.content:
Why this happens is because, Planned order in 1003 ‚Üí converted to STR (PR with doc type for stock transfer). MRP in 1008 sees the requirement element (planned order/STR) regardless of release status. Release strategy in MM controls whether the requisition can be converted into a PO, but it does not block MRP from considering the requirement. Hence, MD04 in 1008 shows the dependent requirement even for STRs that are not yet approved.

Options to handle this

1. Use Release Indicator to Control MRP Relevance
In release strategy configuration SPRO ‚Üí Materials Management ‚Üí Purchasing ‚Üí Purchase Requisition ‚Üí Release Procedure, you can set the release indicator to determine whether the requisition is ‚Äúblocked‚Äù for further processing. If you configure the release indicator so that unreleased STRs are not relevant for MRP, then only approved STRs will be considered in the supplying plant. This requires customizing the release indicator to affect MRP explosion. This requires careful customizing because unreleased STRs remain in the requesting plant, but are not exploded into dependent requirements in the supplying plant until the release indicator changes to ‚ÄúReleased.‚Äù In practice, this is achieved by using different release indicators tied to different processing flags (e.g., ‚Äúblocked for follow‚Äëon processing‚Äù).

2. Separate Document Types for STRs
Use a different PR document type for STRs that are subject to release. Configure MRP so that only requisitions with a certain document type (or release status) are considered in the supplying plant. This way, unreleased STRs remain invisible to MRP in 1008.

3. BAdI / User Exit Enhancement
Standard SAP does not automatically exclude unreleased STRs from MRP. You can use enhancement spots such as BAdI MD_PURREQ_RELEASE or exits in MRP run to filter out unreleased STRs. This is a common approach when business requires strict dependency on release approval.

4. Workflow / Process Control
Instead of trying to block MRP, you can control the timing of MRP runs in plant 1008. Run MRP in 1008 only after STRs in 1003 have been approved. This is a process workaround rather than configuration, but it ensures dependent requirements are aligned with approvals.

entry.title: Cloud connector to cloud alm configuration
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are currently working on connecting the Cloud Connector to the cloud and enabling Health Monitoring in Cloud ALM.

While reviewing the SAP Help Portal documentation, we noticed that it mentions the need to create LDAP-based user management for data collection to push data from the Cloud Connector to Cloud ALM.

Could you please clarify the following points:

  • Is it PERSON_NAME to implement LDAP-based user management for this configuration?
  • Can we assign the required monitoring roles to the existing admin user and proceed without LDAP?
  • If LDAP-based configuration is implemented, we observed that the admin user becomes inactive. Could you confirm if this is expected behavior?

Your guidance on the above queries would be greatly appreciated.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Cloud connector to cloud alm configuration
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Greetings from SAP Support.

Please find our clarification below:

 

1.Is it mandatory to implement LDAP-based user management for this configuration?

No, LDAP-based user management is not mandatory for enabling data collection from SAP Cloud Connector to SAP Cloud ALM.

Cloud Connector has just one Administrator user named Administrator by default. It is possible to change the name and password of this user but it is not possible to add additional users.

To be able to add additional users to Cloud Connector, technically it is required to configure the Cloud Connector to use an LDAP user store.

See KBA3528028 - Cloud Connector user requirements to connect to Cloud ALM - SAP for Me 

 

2.Can we assign the required monitoring roles to the existing admin user and proceed without LDAP?

Yes. You can assign the required monitoring and data collection roles directly to the existing Cloud Connector administrator user and proceed without configuring LDAP-based user management. 

 

3.If LDAP-based configuration is implemented, we observed that the admin user becomes inactive. Could you confirm if this is expected behavior?

Yes, this is expected behavior.

Once configured, the default Cloud Connector Administrator user becomes inactive and can no longer be used to log on to the Cloud Connector. 

See Help Portal https://help.sap.com/docs/connectivity/sap-btp-connectivity-cf/configure-named-cloud-connector-users

 

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: Material Ledger handling for Group Valuation (4G) whe...
entry.content:
Good day @edoymaner 

Thank you for your question

There are a few aspects to consider in your quest.

  • You cannot technically deactivate Group Valuation once you have activated it. This means that 4G valuation view will continue to receive postings from your goods movements and invoice receipts, even if you do not use it for your reporting acitivities.
  • You cannot run CKMLCP in public cloud as it is an on premise-based term. In public cloud, you can execute the same business function through the use of the Fiori actual costing apps and closing tasks. So, the question becomes: Do you need to run actual costing closing steps for 4G valuation view?.
  • You can usually minimise or avoid 4G effort by not processing 4G in the actual costing run template, as long as you are not using any of the 4G results (such as prices, revaluation, actual cost component split) operationally or for your reporting.

Best practice approach is to:

  1. Configure your settings in a way so that your Group Valuation produces the same result as Legal Valuation. Keep the approaches aligned and avoid any configuration that intentionally creates different valuation result between legal and group. See Configuration and Actual Costing Run Result Activity Data for more details.
  2. Run the ML actual costing as normal but treat 4G in your operations as not for reporting. Make sure you keep reporting and business users on Legal valuation views only.
  3. Reduce your effort by automating and not by excluding configuration. Considering the public cloud does not provide the option to exclude valuation view 4G from ML closing, the realistic way to minimise your effort is to schedule the period end steps and standardise a checklist so 4G is always closed together with the other views. See Actual Costing Run Result Activity Data for more insights.
  4. If you keep 4G aligned the extra view should remain low impact. Monitor price differences and your settlement outcomes. If any differences appear, they should usually indicate a divergence in your currency setup or your valuation logic but not a missing step.

To summarise:

  • Active Valuation in public cloud behaves as n active valuation view in ML.
  • You cannot configure ML to skip period end processing only for the 4G view.
  • Keep Group Valuation neutral by aligning valuation logic with legal.
  • Run ML actual costing and close steps as normal, while you restrict reporting to Legal valuation views.
  • Doing these will minimise your effort without you trying any unsupported deactivation patterns.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud - Copy inspection results from SFG to FG
entry.content:
With 200, the system expects a clear link between the FG inspection lot and the SFG inspection lot via the material master and inspection plan hierarchy. If that link isn‚Äôt established, the system cannot ‚Äúfind‚Äù the preliminary product lot and throws the error.

Check the below areas

In the FG material master, the preliminary product (SFG) must be defined correctly in the BOM/routing so that the system knows which inspection lot belongs to the preliminary product. If the FG inspection lot cannot trace back to the SFG material, the copy fails.

The FG inspection plan must reference the MICs with Results Data Origin = 200. The SFG inspection lot must exist and be completed before the FG lot is created. Otherwise, the system won‚Äôt find it.

The SFG inspection lot must be in a status where results are recorded and available (e.g., RREC). If the lot is still open or not valuated, the system won‚Äôt allow copying.

Since 300 is not available, you cannot manually select lots. The system only auto‚Äëlinks based on the preliminary product relationship. That means the prerequisite is: the FG inspection lot must have a direct predecessor lot for the SFG material, otherwise the error appears.

entry.title: Re: BOM can only be extended via Master Recipe
entry.content:
Below are the likely root causes

  • The material in question is probably maintained with a recipe‚Äëbased production process (Process Manufacturing) rather than discrete manufacturing.
  • In SAP, materials flagged for process industries (PI) use Master Recipes instead of BOMs for component assignment.
  • That‚Äôs why when you try CS01 (create BOM), the system tells you ‚ÄúBOM can only be extended via Master Recipe.‚Äù
  • For such materials, the system expects you to maintain the component structure in the Master Recipe (transaction C201/C202), not in a BOM.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany stock transfer what happens when a lower...
entry.content:
In your case, what happens when quantities differ is as follows:

NBIC order creation:
Represents the expected inbound from the vendor/3rd party warehouse.

Putaway message via Boomi:
Updates the inbound delivery with the actual quantity received at the external warehouse.

Job posting GR:
Moves stock from ‚Äúin transit‚Äù into the receiving plant‚Äôs available stock.

If the actual received quantity ‚â† ordered quantity:

Less stock arrives:
You post GR for the actual received quantity. The NBIC order remains partially open until you either receive the remainder or close it. To close, you must reduce the inbound delivery quantity (adjust delivery against PO) so that the open balance is zero. The difference is then cleared, and stock in transit is reduced accordingly.

More stock arrives:
You cannot post more than the ordered quantity against the NBIC order. The excess must be handled by creating a new NBIC order/inbound delivery or by adjusting the PO/inbound delivery quantity before GR. Otherwise, the system will reject the GR posting.

Do roles in the implementation phase need to be assigned individually?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: About SAP Cloud ALM roles
entry.content:
Available Roles outlines that Role Collection "Cross Global Administrator" permits users to "Create and manage all SAP Cloud ALM objects, except for personal or sensitive data". 

Role Collection "Cross Global Administrator" should only be assigned to a user fulfilling the role of Administrator for the SAP Cloud ALM tenant. It should not be used for general day-to-day work. Instead, more specific role collections should be assigned to the users based on the tasks that they will perform. SAP Cloud ALM has documented these role collections and categorized them based on several scenarios:

  • Implementation
  • Transformation
  • Operations
  • Service
  • Administration
  • RISE with SAP Methodology

Additional information about the Implementation scenario can be found in KBAs 3499177 and 3643702.

entry.title: The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas
entry.content:
Introduction

You can use the various objects in an IF condition.  Among them, the behavior of comparing a dimension member with another dimension member from a different dimension, or with a dimension property (which is also a dimension member), is explained through an example.

 

IF with dimension combination filters

You can define a dimension combination filter that produces a scope of dimension member combinations based on whether or not the other dimension ID or dimension properties match.

 

Example

Compare the Dimension with the Other dimension property

Model & Dimension

Company_Code Dimension

Cost_Center Dimension

 

Calculation Source

 

 

Case 1:  [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] = [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

     Calculated Result

    All combinations of Company Code (100 or 200) and the CompanyCode property (100, 200, or 300) return true.

    As a result, six records are deleted.

 

 

Case 2:  [d/Company_Code] != [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] != [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   There are no combinations other than all combinations of Company Code (100 or 200) and the CompanyCode property (100, 200, or 300). Therefore, no records are deleted.

 

 

Case 3:  [d/Company_Code] == [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] == [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   For each record, the combination where the Company Code and the CompanyCode property match returns true. As a result, two records are deleted.

 

 

Case 4:  [d/Company_Code] !== [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode]

MEMBERSET [d/Company_Code] = ("100", "200")
MEMBERSET [d/Cost_Center] = ("CC100", "CC200","CC300")

IF [d/Company_Code] !== [d/Cost_Center].[p/CompanyCode] THEN
	DELETE()
ENDIF

   Calculated Result

   For each record, the combinations where the Company Code and the CompanyCode property do not match return true. As a result, 4 records are deleted.

 

Thanks,

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Co
entry.content: The error occurs because the sales order item isn‚Äôt set as cost-relevant. To fix it, ensure the item category in the sales order (via VOV7) is configured for item costing, and that the sales document type and material support costing before assigning it to the service order.

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud custom po header condition for freig...
entry.content:
Good day @R971 

Thank you for your question

It is important to note that, in PO pricing, the system considers Amount as rate, while condition value is the calculated value after the system has applied the condition across items. So, if your custom condition is currently being treated as an item applied condition, the system will apply the 50 to each PO item and the condition value becomes 100 when there are two items.

If the 50 is your total for the whole PO, then you must configure your condition and use it as a header condition with distribution.

I suggest you evaluate the following:

First step:

  • You open your Purchasing Calculation Schema where your condition is used. Then open the ZFIN condition type and verify you have configured it as a Header condition and not item.
  • Ensure it also supports Header distribution, so one header amount is distributed to item rather than copied to each of them. See Purchasing Pricing Condition Record Events for more details.

Second step:

In your Manage Purchase Orders app, open your PO, go to your conditions at header level and enter your total freight 50. Use the distribution function so the system splits the 50 across items (based on your configuration, this is usually by item value or quantity).

Third step:

After you have carried out the distribution, header should show total of 50, items should show prorated values sum of 50 and your PO total should reflect the correct overall freight.

If you cannot change your configuration now, you can get to 50 total for 2 items by entering 25. This is suggested as a workaround and not a long-term solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAP public cloud custom po header condition for freig...
entry.content:
Dear @R971,

Your condition type is acting as a non-group condition

SAP behavior is documented for Public Cloud:

  • Group condition = ON, system distributes the header condition value to items proportionally and sum of items = header value
  • Group condition = OFF, system copies the same value to every item

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3618341

That exactly explains why each PO item gets the same 50

To fix this you need two things:

Point 1. Fix the condition type

In CBC go to 101094(Define Condition Types - Set Pricing Condition Types ‚Äì Purchasing)

For ZFIN:

1. Set the Calculation Type to match your intent:

    • If you want 50 total per PO, use Fixed Amount, not per unit/quantity

2. Set Group Condition = ON so that header entry gets distributed, not copied

SAP Note below as example:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003618341

Point 2. Fix the calculation schema / pricing procedure line

In CBC go to 101095(Set Calculation Schema ‚Äì Purchasing) and ensure:

1. ZFIN is marked as a Header condition line in the schema header indicator on the pricing-procedure line

2. You do not have ZFIN duplicated as an item condition line in the same schema that can also lead to unexpected doubling/copying

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003043325

Point 3. Re-test the PO

After transporting the config:

  • Enter 50 at header for ZFIN
  • Items should show distributed amounts
  • Sum of item condition values = 50, not 100

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Cloud BAdIs to Check Sales Document and Items
entry.content:
Cloud BAdIs to Check Sales Document and Items

As I explained in blog Sales Document BAdI Overview, there are Cloud BAdIs to perform validation checks for entities of sales document in different processing phases. 

  • Check of Header Data in Sales Documents - SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD
  • Check of Item Data in Sales Documents - SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEM
  • Check of Delivery Schedule Data in Sales Scheduling Agreements - SD_SLS_CHECK_DELIVSCHED
  • Check of Sales Document Items Before Deletion - SD_SLS_CHECK_DELETE_ITEM
  • Check of Sales Documents Before Saving - SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE

Sales Document Entity Check BAdIs

Following Cloud BAdIs are used to check on certain sales document entities (business context), relevant messages can be raised from the BAdI implementation logic. These BAdIs are processed in transactional manner which means these BAdIs will be triggered multiple times during sales document processing. 

BAdI NameDescriptionBusiness ContextPurpose/Usage
SD_SLS_CHECK_HEADCheck of Header Data in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales DocumentYou can implement custom logic to check sales document header data and raise messages
SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEMCheck of Item Data in Sales DocumentsSales: Sales Document ItemYou can implement custom logic to check sales document item and raise messages
SD_SLS_CHECK_DELIVSCHED
Check of Delivery Schedule Data in Sales Scheduling AgreementsSales: Sales Scheduling Agreement Delivery ScheduleYou can implement custom logic to check sales scheduling agreement delivery schedule and raise messages

It is important to know that messages raised in above BAdI implementation will not prevent from saving the sales documents, even for the error messages. 

Following message types are supported:

  • I - Information message
  • W - Warning message
  • E - Error message

Parameters of BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD

There are following parameters defined in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
DOCUMENTPROCESSINGMODESales Document Processing ModeImporting

Contains information on whether the document is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY

SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales Document PartnersImportingContains sales document header partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENT_EXTENSIONSales Document Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document header
MESSAGESMessagesChangingCustomer can pass any message texts (free text) with allowed message types into this parameter

Parameters of BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEM

There are following parameters defined in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEM

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
DOCUMENTPROCESSINGMODESales Document Processing ModeImporting

Contains information on whether the document is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY

DOCUMENTITEMPROCESSINGMODESales Document Item Processing ModeImportingContains information on whether the document item is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTSCHEDULELINESSales Document Schedule LinesImportingContains information about sales document schedule lines
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales Document PartnersImportingContains sales document header partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMPARTNERSSales Document Item PartnersImportingContains sales document item partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENT_EXTENSIONSales Document Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document header
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_EXTENSION
Sales Document Item Custom FieldImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document item
MESSAGESMessagesChangingCustomer can pass any message texts (free text) with allowed message types into this parameter

Parameters of BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_DELIVSCHED

There are following parameters defined in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_DELIVSCHED

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
DOCUMENTPROCESSINGMODESales Document Processing ModeImporting

Contains information on whether the document is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY

DOCUMENTITEMPROCESSINGMODESales Document Item Processing ModeImportingContains information on whether the document item is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data currently being processed
DELIVERYSCHEDULESales Scheduling Agreement Delivery ScheduleImportingContains information about the sales scheduling agreement delivery schedules currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENT_EXTENSIONSales Document Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document header
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_EXTENSIONSales Document Item Custom FieldImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document item
DELIVERYSCHEDULE _EXTENSIONSales Scheduling Agreement Delivery Schedule Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales scheduling agreement delivery schedules
MESSAGESMessagesChangingCustomer can pass any message texts (free text) with allowed message types into this parameter

Check BAdI for Sales Document Item Deletion 

This BAdI is defined to allow customers implement custom logic to control whether deletion of sales document item is possible or not. This BAdI is called as soon as the sales document item deletion occurs. The check results can be communicated via messages to be added to a message table. 

There are following parameters defined in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_DELETE_ITEM

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
DOCUMENTPROCESSINGMODESales Document Processing ModeImporting

Contains information on whether the document is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY

DOCUMENTITEMPROCESSINGMODESales Document Item Processing ModeImportingContains information on whether the document item is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY
SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales Document PartnersImportingContains sales document header partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMPARTNERSSales Document Item PartnersImportingContains sales document item partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENT_EXTENSIONSales Document Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document header
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_EXTENSION
Sales Document Item Custom FieldImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document item
OPERATIONCONTEXT
Sales document operation contextImportingContains information about the context of the current operation
NO_DELETION
No DeletionChangingan be filled with value X to disallow deletion of the item
MESSAGESMessagesChangingCustomer can pass any message texts (free text) with allowed message types into this parameter

Following message types are supported:

  • I - Information message
  • W - Warning message
  • E - Error message

Sales Document Check Before Save BAdI

Different from above check BAdIs, the Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE is called in sales document saving phase. Customer can implement custom logic to check sales document data before save and decide to abort the document saving. The check results can be communicated via messages to be added to a message table. 

There are following parameters defined in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_DELETE_ITEM

Parameter NameDescriptionParameter TypePurpose
DOCUMENTPROCESSINGMODESales Document Processing ModeImporting

Contains information on whether the document is currently in one of the following processing modes: CREATE, CHANGE, or DISPLAY

SALESDOCUMENTSales document headerImportingContains sales document header data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMSSales document itemImportingContains sales document item data currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTSCHEDULELINES
Sales document schedule lineImportingContains information about sales document schedule lines
SALESDOCUMENTPARTNERSSales Document PartnersImportingContains sales document header partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENTITEMPARTNERSSales Document Item PartnersImportingContains sales document item partners currently being processed
SALESDOCUMENT_EXTENSIONSales Document Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document header
SALESDOCUMENTITEM_EXTENSION
Sales Document Item Custom FieldImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales document item
DELIVERYSCHEDULESales Scheduling Agreement Delivery ScheduleImportingContains information about the sales scheduling agreement delivery schedules currently being processed
DELIVERYSCHEDULE _EXTENSIONSales Scheduling Agreement Delivery Schedule Custom FieldsImportingContains the values of extension fields for the sales scheduling agreement delivery schedules
ELECTRONICPAYMENTDETAILSElectronic Payment Details  ImportingContains information about electronic payment details of the sales document currently being processed
MESSAGESMessagesChangingCustomer can pass any message texts (free text) with allowed message types into this parameter

Following message types are supported:

  • I - Information message
  • W - Warning message
  • E - Error message

Only the error message will prevent from saving the sales document. 

Key Benefit of Check Before Save BAdI

There are following key features of sales document check before save BAdI:

  • Based on validation check result, you can stop saving the sales document 
  • You will get more reliable sales document data in check before save BAdI because the sales document data is relatively more stable in saving phase
  • You have full access of sales document entities in check before save BAdI
  • The check before save BAdI is more performant as it is only called once during document saving

Business Example 

I'd like to use a business example to explain how to utilize check BAdIs to fulfill a business requirement. 

Supplier company XYZ sells products to different customers. The customer order can be placed via Portal as self-service or placed manually by the sales representative. 

Due to fluctuations in the prices of raw materials, company XYZ generally does not accept customer orders with long-term delivery requests. Company XYZ would like to implement custom logic to indicate the issue of long-term delivery and stop saving the sales order if it is requested to be delivered later than 1 month from the order creation date. 

Solution via Extensibility

The BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD and BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE can work together to fulfill the requirement. 

Implement Custom Logic in SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD

As explained above, the BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD can perform custom validation check during sales document processing, and this BAdI will not impact on the sales document save. 

I can implement custom logic to indicate there is an issue when customer requested delivery date is too long. 

Create a BAdI implementation for Cloud BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD.

Implement below custom logic to raise an error message when customer requested delivery date is 30 days away.

* show error message if the customer requested delivery date is later than 30 days
  if documentprocessingmode = 'CREATE' or documentprocessingmode = 'CHANGE'.
    if salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA' or salesdocument-soldtoparty = '0010100080'.
    "check is customer requested delivery date is more than 30 days from today
      if salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate - salesdocument-creationdate > 30.
        append value #( messagetype = 'E' messagetext = 'Customer Requested Date has to be within 30 days.' ) to messages.
      endif.
    endif.
  endif.

Publish the BAdI and test the sales order creation from Fiori application. 

Create a sales order for customer "10100080". When I set the requested delivery date to Feb 1st 2026, I get the error message notified in the sales order UI.

But I can continue with clicking the Create button to save the sales order.

A dialog box is popped up before continuing saving the sales order.

Press save button to continue. Eventually the sales order can be saved. 

Implement Custom Logic in SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE

In order to reduce the risk of creating sales orders with long customer requested delivery date, we can implement custom logic in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE to prevent from saving the sales order if the customer requested delivery date is 30 days away. 

Create a BAdI implementation for SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE.

Implement custom logic below to check requested delivery date and raise an error message if the customer requested delivery date is 30 days away from order creation date.

* Check if the customer requested delivery date is 30 days later from the order creation date
* The sales order shall not be saved if the customer requested delivery date is later than 30 days
  if documentprocessingmode = 'CREATE' or documentprocessingmode = 'CHANGE'.
    if salesdocument-salesdocumenttype = 'TA'.
      "get sold-to party
      read table salesdocumentpartners into data(ls_partner) with key partnerfunction = 'AG'.
      if ls_partner-customer = '0010100080'.
        "check is customer requested delivery date is more than 30 days from today
        if salesdocument-requesteddeliverydate - salesdocument-creationdate > 30.
          append value #( messagetype = 'E' messagetext = 'Customer Requested Date has to be within 30 days.' ) to messages.
        endif.
      endif.
    endif.
  endif.

Publish the BAdI implementation and test sales order behavior in Fiori UI.

Create a sales order with customer "10100080" and set the customer requested delivery date to Feb 1st 2026. 

The error message is raised from the implementation of BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD.

Click button "Save" to try to save the sales order. 

The error message is raised and sales order save is failed. It is because the error message raised in BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE prevent the document save. 

Moving Forward

Now, I believe I have better understanding of different Cloud BAdIs to perform validation checks against sales document.

You can use transactional BAdIs to perform validation check at runtime, especially when you use sales document UI to create/update sales documents. The BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_HEAD and SD_SLS_CHECK_ITEM are processed whenever the relevant entities are in processing. 

The BAdI SD_SLS_CHECK_BEFORE_SAVE is triggered only once before save. You can access to all entities of sales document to perform validation check with more reliable value. It is possible to stop saving if the validation check is failed in custom logic. 

In the future, according to customer requirements, the check BAdIs would be enhanced to support more import parameters and entities. Please feel free to submit your requirement through the Customer Influence Portal, see detail in SAP note 2963059. Stay tuned for new features planned in our roadmap.

entry.title: IFRS 18 Compliance for TRM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Key Impacts and Approaches
entry.content:
IFRS 18 at a glace

The International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) issued IFRS 18 Presentation and Disclosure in Financial Statements in April 2024. IFRS 18 replaces IAS 1 Presentation of Financial Statements, requirements in IAS 1 that are unchanged have been transferred to IFRS 18 and other Standards. IFRS 18 is effective from 1 January 2027, companies are permitted to apply IFRS 18 before that date.

IFRS 18 aims to improve how companies communicate in their financial statements, with a focus on information about financial performance in the statement of profit or loss. IFRS 18 will affect all companies in all industries. Although IFRS 18 will not affect how companies measure financial performance, it will affect how companies present and disclose financial performance.

The main changes introduced by IFRS 18 include, but are not limited to:

  • In the statement of profit or loss ‚Äî report two new defined subtotals including operating profit, based on a new set of requirements for classifying income and expenses in categories. The newly introduced categories are Operating, Investing and Financing.
  • In the notes ‚Äî disclose information about some performance measures defined by management, which IFRS 18 identify as ‚Äòmanagement-defined performance measures‚Äô (MPMs).
  • In both the primary financial statements and the notes ‚Äî group items applying enhanced requirements for aggregation and disaggregation of information.

 

Purpose of this blog

With one year to go before IFRS 18 becomes officially effective, we are publishing this blog to provide corporate treasurers, treasury accountants and implementation partners who use or implement Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with early insights into the presentation of financial performance arising from TRM module (primarily TRM postings relate to profit or loss) and configuration changes ‚Äî required to prepare the statement of profit or loss that is fully compliant with the new standard.

 

Impacts on Treasury and Risk Management

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Treasury and Risk Management (TRM) supports the management and measurement of debt, investments, and financial risks through a wide range of financial instruments, including OTC money market transactions, foreign exchange deals, securities, derivatives, and trade finance instruments.

The following mapping matrix outlines, at a detailed level, the potential relationships between profit or loss related line-item elements (classified in IFRS 18 categories) and TRM product categories/product types (as covered in the current scope of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).

From the matrix, you may see that the income and expenses arising from TRM may fall into any of the three categories required by IFRS 18 ‚Äî Operating, Investing, or Financing ‚Äî depending on the economic nature of the financial instrument and the business purpose for which the entity holds or uses it.

When preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IAS 1, usually it is sufficient that the TRM-generated posting journals only reflect the ‚Äúnature‚Äù of the income or expenses, for example, the G/L account ‚Äúfair value gain or loss‚Äù is sufficient for recognizing the gains or losses arising from the fair value changes on financial assets (or liabilities when applicable) which are evaluated at ‚Äúfair value through profit or loss (FVTPL)‚Äù under IFRS 9. However, when preparing the statement of profit or loss applying IFRS 18, a single G/L account "fair value gains or losses" is insufficiently granular, as it fails to reflect which category ‚Äî or, to use a more direct term, the "function" ‚Äî for classifying such income or expenses: operating, investing, or financing.

 

Implementation approaches

To achieve fine-grained detail within TRM-generated posting journals while also reflecting the categories (operating, investing, or financing), basically two approaches are available:

Approach 1: via granular G/L accounts

Set up profit or loss accounts with enhanced granularity, such that each account maps unequivocally to one of the IFRS 18 presentation categories or ‚Äúfunctions‚Äù (representing operating, investing, or financing), in addition to their ‚Äúnature‚Äù. Under this approach, certain profit or loss accounts will need to be ‚Äúduplicated threefold‚Äù (once for each category).

A clear disadvantage of this approach is the potential need to create an unnecessarily large number of ‚Äúredundant‚Äù accounts, particularly if additional dimensions (e.g., relationship with the counterparty/issuer) need to be incorporated into the account structure as well.

Approach 2: via functional areas

Limit profit or loss accounts to reflecting only their ‚Äúnature‚Äù, eliminating the need to create new G/L accounts (which is the major advantage of Approach 2). Instead, leverage functional areas to differentiate between the three presentation categories during the generation of posting journals from TRM, and the functional area should be from TRM OTC transactions or security positions.

An ensuing question is how the functional area is determined for TRM OTC transactions or security positions ‚Äî this will be addressed in the next section.

 

Implementation advice

This section outlines key configuration considerations for achieving successful implementation of Approach 1 or Approach 2.

Approach 1: via granular G/L accounts

To implement Approach 1, first, please create additional fine-grained profit or loss accounts in General Ledger Accounting.

A critical subsequent consideration is how to determine the appropriate G/L account from the TRM module. As a key dimension for G/L account determination in TRM, Account Assignment References (AARs) shall be configured such that IFRS 18 categories (operating, investing, financing) are encoded in their IDs and names. This means AARs will need to be triplicated relative to those required for IAS 1-compliant profit or loss presentation requirements. AARs are created through configuration activity 102099 Define Account Assignment References.

The next critical configuration step is to derive AARs for OTC transactions and security positions. To accomplish this, please configure substitution rules for AAR derivation based on pre-conditions including (but not limited to) product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, and hedging classification, etc. For guidance on using the relevant substitution tools, refer to the help documentations:

  • Account Assignment References - OTC Transactions (Substitution Rules)
  • Account Assignment References - Securities (Substitution Rules)

The following table outlines potential pre-conditions for deriving AARs across different TRM product categories or product types:

As the last step, please assign the new G/L accounts to account symbols and new AARs via configuration activity 103014 Define Account Determination for Treasury and Risk Management.

Approach 2: via functional areas

Approach 2 eliminates the need for additional G/L accounts. However, IFRS 18 presentation category granularity must still be embedded in new AARs, as the derivation of functional areas is dependent on the AARs. Additionally, substitution rules for new AARs derivation and the configuration for assignment of existing G/L accounts to account symbols and new AARs remain necessary.

Beyond the configurations outlined in Approach 1, Approach 2 requires the following additional configurations:

  • Create new functional areas to represent the three IFRS 18 categories (Operating, Investing, Financing) via configuration activity 102363 Define Functional Area.
  • In configuration activity 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References, assign the new functional areas to company codes and new AARs accordingly.

Once the above configurations are completed, the functional area will be populated in the Position Indicator of newly created OTC transactions and security positions, following this determination sequence:

  • Substitution rule derives the relevant AAR based on pre-conditions (e.g., product category, product type, transaction category, transaction type, valuation class, portfolio, hedging classification).
  • The configuration in activity 105341 determines the functional area from the company code and the already derived AAR. The functional area is then stored in the Position Indicator.

Subsequently, the functional area in the Position Indicator is propagated to the corresponding posting journals generated from TRM transactions and security positions. Moreover, the functional area supplied by the TRM position indicator (as the calling application) takes precedence over that derived from G/L account master data or account assignment (e.g., cost center, WBS element), if applicable. For further details, please refer to SAP help document: Deriving Functional Areas.

Considerations for the Implementation Project Timeline

IFRS 18 will be effective from 1 January 2027, meaning related financial statements for annual reporting periods beginning on or after this date must be prepared in accordance with this new standard.

Accordingly, the following TRM-related deliverables must be completed prior to the start of the 2027 fiscal year (for production tenants where TRM will have been in productive use by the end of 2026) or prior to the TRM go-live date (for production tenants where TRM will be in productive use in 2027 or later):

  • Align TRM business processes and posting requirements with IFRS 18 mandates. More specifically, determine whether to adopt Approach 1, Approach 2, or any other viable methodologies not described in this blog.
  • Update system configurations, or activate IFRS 18-related SAP Best Practice content (scope item) and fine-tune the system configurations accordingly (Please refer to the section ‚ÄúSAP best practice content‚Äù for details).
  • Conduct end-to-end testing of TRM business processes and posting results in the test tenant.
  • Transport validated configurations to the production tenant, and run account assignment reference transfer if necessary (please refer to the section ‚ÄúOutstanding transactions and security positions‚Äù for details).

The implementation for TRM may form part of a larger initiative (e.g., a company-wide IFRS 18 compliance program or an ERP implementation project). Additionally, considerations for how to incorporate and aggregate TRM-generated profit or loss posting journals into individual (and consolidated, if applicable) statement of profit or loss are also critical but not elaborated upon in this blog.

 

Outstanding transactions and security positions

For production tenants where TRM will have been in productive use by the end of 2026 (or by the planned transition date to IFRS 18-aligned processes following configuration updates), all outstanding OTC transactions and security positions must be ‚Äúconverted‚Äù to ensure that subsequent postings generated from these transactions or positions are IFRS 18-compliant.

To facilitate this ‚Äúconversion‚Äù, the functionality Transfer Account Assignment Reference (App ID: TPM28) is recommended.

Executing TPM28 performs the following core actions:

  • Transfers existing (legacy) Account Assignment References (AARs) to new, IFRS 18-compliant AARs. New AARs will appear in the Position Indicator of OTC transactions and security positions afterwards.
  • Posts position transfers at book value between the old and new AARs ‚Äî specifically, it clears the position using the position account derived from the legacy AAR and re-recognizes the same position using the position account determined by the new IFRS 18-compliant AAR.

However, this ‚Äúconversion‚Äù typically does not invoke changes to position accounts. As such, the position transfer postings generated by TPM28 are unnecessary. To suppress these postings, it is recommended to mark relevant update types as non-posting relevant.

If Approach 2 (via functional areas) is adopted, execution of TPM28 will bring another update within the position indicator ‚Äî the functional area (determined via configuration activity 105341 Allocate Additional Account Assignments to Account Assignment References) will be populated in the position indicator, associated to the new AAR.

TPM28 includes a checkbox: ‚ÄúTransfer of P&L Postings‚Äù. Enabling this indicator triggers the transfer of all related profit or loss postings for the current fiscal year up to the TPM28‚Äôs key date ‚Äî legacy profit or loss postings derived from the old AAR are cleared, and profit or loss postings are re-recognized based on the new AAR. For Approach 2, these re-recognition postings will also include the relevant functional area.

Using TPM28 with the ‚ÄúTransfer of P&L Postings‚Äù indicator enabled fulfills IFRS 18‚Äôs requirement for the restatement of profit or loss for comparative period (typically the 2026 fiscal year). To achieve this, TPM28 is supposed to executed at the end of the fiscal year 2026.

For further details, please refer to the SAP Help document: Transfer Account Assignment Reference.

 

Embed ‚Äòcategorization' throughout the E2E hedging process

Appropriate categorization of profit or loss is a fundamental requirement for applying IFRS 18 within TRM. However, some TRM users may have additional requirements beyond this ‚Äî for instance, embedding the concept of ‚Äòcategorization‚Äô across the entire end-to-end hedging process for foreign exchange (FX) risk.

Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures (FX Risk)

Within the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures (FX Risk) functionality, the Hedge Management Cockpit app serves as the central tool, providing a consolidated overview of FX exposures and the corresponding hedging instruments used to mitigate FX risk within a defined hedging area.

The exposures managed by the Hedge Management Cockpit usually arise from variability in cash flows that is attributable to FX risks associated with highly probable forecast transactions, unrecognized firm commitments, or recognized assets or liabilities.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this E2E net open exposure hedging process, the setup of Hedging Areas (the process starting point) must include differentiation criteria ‚Äî such as portfolio ‚Äî to represent IFRS 18 categories for both exposures and hedges.

Accordingly, when the FX exposures are created, the IFRS 18 category-representative portfolio must be explicitly specified in the exposures to differentiate exposure categories. This portfolio will then propagate throughout the entire process, including:

  • Snapshots of exposures
  • Hedge requests
  • Trade requests (if Trading Platform Integration is enabled)
  • Ultimately, the hedging instruments themselves (e.g., FX forwards, FX options)

The substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition, enabling the derivation of category-representative Account Assignment References (AARs) for the hedging instruments. Subsequently, all posting journals generated from these hedging instruments will be IFRS 18-compliant ‚Äî regardless of whether aforementioned Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

Hedge Management of Balance Sheet FX Risk

The Hedge Management of Balance Sheet FX Risk functionality is designed to capture the FX exposures arising from the changes in fair value of recognized assets or liabilities that are attributable to FX risk, and facilitate the conduction of corresponding hedging instruments to mitigate such risks.

To incorporate IFRS 18 categories into this end-to-end balance sheet FX risk hedging process, balance sheet FX exposures must include category-related information at the process outset. To achieve this, it is recommended to create distinct category-representative Key Figure Groups, which can be differentiated based on criteria such as G/L accounts.

Subsequent steps include:

  • Generating snapshots based on these distinct Key Figure Groups ‚Äî these snapshots will also be segregated by the IFRS 18 categories.
  • Creating hedge requests separately from each snapshot. During this step, explicitly assign the corresponding category-representative portfolio to each snapshot, ensuring hedge requests are segregated by the IFRS 18 categories via the portfolio dimension.
  • If Trading Platform Integration is enabled, trade requests will inherit the portfolio from the corresponding hedge requests.
  • Ultimately, the hedging instruments (e.g., FX forwards, FX options) will be linked to the relevant category-representative portfolios.

Similar to the Hedge Management of Net Open Exposures process, the substitution rules can be configured using the portfolio as a pre-condition to derive category-specific AARs for the hedging instruments. Posting journals generated from these hedging instruments will then be IFRS 18-compliant ‚Äî regardless of whether Approach 1 (via granular G/L accounts) or Approach 2 (via functional areas) is implemented.

 

SAP best practice content

SAP plans to deliver additional Best Practice content through the introduction of new scope item(s) as part of the 2608 release. Please stay tuned for updates, which will also be posted on this blog.

We expect this additional content to streamline the TRM implementation journey related to IFRS 18 compliance, particularly for new customers, for whom TRM will not be placed into productive use until the implementation of IFRS 18 is finalized.

Please note that this plan is subject to change.

entry.title: How to use a CAP business service to manage DMQ messages on SAP Advanced Event Mesh
entry.content:
Context

A message that reaches SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh is moved to a Dead Message Queue (DMQ) when it's 'Time to live' (TTL) has passed or when the number of delivery attempts to the consumer has been exceeded. Once the TTL of messages in the DMQ has passed the message broker deletes affected messages irrevocably. Message deletion might not be acceptable in the related integration scenario.

This blog post describes how to create a CAP business service that retrieves DMQ messages from SAP Advanced Event Mesh for quarantine. Retrieving DMQ messages from the message broker before their TTL ends safeguards messages from deletion and keeps the messages alive in quarantine. Using management features like payload inspection, quarantined messages can be reinjected into SAP Advanced Event Mesh to reattempt delivery to the original consumer.

Create CAP project

Using SAP Build Code, in a Dev Space of type 'Full-Stack Application Using Productivity Tools', create a multi-target application project using the project from template wizard 'Full Stack Project'.

CAP schema definition

Using CDS create a DB schema.cds, that caters for entities SourceQueue and QueueMessage. The SourceQueue is for configuration of the DMQs whose messages should be retrieved for quarantine. The QueueMessage entity is for persisting the retrieved DMQ messages in all relevant aspects for inspection and resubmission to SAP Advanced Event Mesh. For the binary payload use CAP type LargeBinary, for the text payload use CAP type LargeString.

CAP service definition

Using CDS create one service whose purpose is to connect a SourceQueue (sourcequeue-connector.cds) and another for managing quarantined messages (queuemessage-manager.cds). In sourcequeue-connector.cds for entity SourceQueue add bound actions openConnection, closeConnection, checkConnection, cleanup and flush. For cleanup we have implemented logic to remove all queue messages that have successfully been resubmitted to SAP Advanced Event Mesh. With 'flush' we cater for resubmission of all messages that remain to be resent to SAP Advanced Event Mesh for the source queue in question. In queuemessage-manager.cds for entity QueueMessage add bound action produce. 

CAP service implementation

Add a sourcequeue-connector.js file in the same location as sourcequeue-connector.cds which CAP by convention of matching names will consider as the module holding custom application logic for the service. Next, for your project do configuration as described in plugin cap-js/advanced-event-mesh. This will equip your project for interaction with SAP Advanced Event Mesh. For action openConnection of entity SourceQueue implement as per the Solace QueueConsumer sample. To receive messages add a handler function for the solace.MessageConsumerEventName.MESSAGE event and write all relevant attributes to the QueueMessage entity using CQL INSERT. Opening a connection from CAP will create a consumer on the queue on SAP Advanced Event Mesh message broker. All messages in the queue on the SAP Advanced Event Mesh message broker at the time of establishing a connection and all new messages entering the DMQ while connected will be consumed and acknowledged by the CAP application. 

Add a queuemessage-manager.js file in the same location as queuemessage-manager.cds which CAP by convention of matching names will consider as the module holding custom application logic for the service. For action produce of entity QueueMessage implement as per the Solace QueueProducer sample to write the quarantined message to the target queue on SAP Advanced Event Mesh.

Fiori Element UIs

Using the Storyboard feature in Build Code add 2 separate List Report Page UIs, one consuming the sourcequeue-connector service and one consuming the queuemessage-manager service. Using the sourcequeue-connector UI users can connect to a DMQ on SAP Advanced Event Mesh and manage the connection. If a DMQ is left in connected state then all messages from the related DMQ are immediately quarantined to the CAP business service. Using the queuemessage-manager UI users can inspect quarantined messages, validate payloads and resubmit them to SAP Advanced Event Mesh. In our implementation of the CAP business service we allow for correcting payloads to cater for situations where the source system cannot reproduce messages.

Fiori Elements visual impressions

This is how our tiles in the launchpad ended up looking:

Here is an impression of the SourceQueue object page of the 'Connect Source Queues' app. Note the buttons for execution of custom actions connect, disconnect, check connection, flush and cleanup from the CDS service definition. The footer action 'Refresh' is a custom action implemented as extension to the Fiori Elements Listreport and Object Page template.

Here is an impression of the QueueMessage object page of the 'Manage Queue Messages' app. Note the button for execution of custom action produce from the CDS service definition.

Special considerations

The following topics deserve special mention as they need to be thought of ahead of creating the CAP business service.

BTP subaccount for deployment

We consider the CAP business service to quarantine DMQ messages from SAP Advanced Event Mesh as enterprise support, i.e. a central support function that should be implemented once per global account. That is why we have chosen a central BTP subaccount dedicated to Enterprise Application Integration for deployment of the CAP business service, i.e. a subaccount that is not dedicated to a line of business.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh (powered by Solace PubSub+) has a concept of 'environments' with which it separates development, test and production artifacts. All environments are managed through the SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh subscription of the one BTP subaccount. To stick to our approach to use BTP subaccounts for separating development, test and production we use the BTP subaccounts dedicated to the respective stage to deploy the CAP business service. It is the user provided service 'advanced-event-mesh' in each subaccount that provides the CAP business service with details about the message broker to connect to. Our development, test and production BTP subaccounts trust different SAP Identity and Authentication Service (IAS) instances and the OAuth Profile that we created on the message brokers accordingly ensure that messages cannot be sent across stages.

Rendering through SAP Build Workzone

For deployment of our CAP business service for DMQ message management we chose the managed app router approach. Due to the fact that our central enterprise launchpad though is running on another BTP subaccount than the one that holds the deployed CAP business service we are exposing it as a 'content provider'. This way we can consume it cross-subaccount from the BTP subaccount that runs our central enterprise launchpad.

entry.title: Re: Unable to find the app to post recurring entry for cu...
entry.content:
Good day @GVKR9 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, in public cloud, recurring postings are provided for recurring journal entries(G/L) but you can typically do recurring customer invoice through periodic billing plans and the standard billing run but not through FI recurring entry transaction.

See the following reference for more details:

Manage Recurring Journal Entries, Billing Plans and Periodic Billing Plans for Service Contract Billing

My suggestion is for you to:

  • Crate the customer contract or sales document that support billing plans
  • In your document item, maintain the Billing Plan with start/end date, Amounts and frequency (monthly, quarterly etc.)
  • At period end, use Create Billing Documents to generate the customer invoices that post to accounting.

In your system, open the contract or sales document item, go to billing plan, maintain your periodic dates and amounts, save. Then run Billing Due List to create the invoices for the due dates.

Alternatively, if you need only periodic G/L posting and not customer invoices, use the Manage Recurring Journal Entries for G/L recurring posting only. See Manage Recurring Journal Entries for more insights.

Let me know if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: sap Cloud authorization Object problem because of namespace to long /asdfghjk/
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We are working in ABAP Cloud and created a custom namespace with 8 characters:

/asdfghjk/
(10 characters total including the slashes)

We already have thousands of CDS views and other objects created under this namespace.

At the final stage of a complex development, we now need to implement CDS Access Control .
For this, we need to create 4 authorization objects and reference them in CDS access controls.

Problem

Authorization object names are limited to 10 characters, and our namespace alone already consumes all 10 characters:

/asdfghjk/

Because of this:

  • We cannot create authorization objects in this namespace (no space left for a name).

  • CDS Access Controls under /asdfghjk/ can only reference authorization objects from the same namespace.

What we tried

  1. Create a shorter namespace /abc/

    • ‚úî We can create authorization objects

    • ‚ùå We cannot use them in CDS Access Controls under /asdfghjk/ because namespaces differ

  2. Create Z authorization objects*

    • ‚ùå Same issue: CDS Access Controls in /asdfghjk/ can only reference objects from /asdfghjk/

Constraint

We cannot move all existing objects from /asdfghjk/ to a shorter namespace ‚Äî this would involve thousands of objects and is not feasible.

Question

Is there any recommended solution or workaround for this situation in ABAP Cloud?

  • Is there a way to reference authorization objects from a different namespace in CDS Access Control?

  • Is there an SAP-recommended approach for long namespaces and authorization objects?

  • Or is this a known limitation with a documented workaround?

Any guidance or best practice would be highly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: issue with duplicate Business Partner / Supplier / Cu...
entry.content:
Dear @SivaNagiReddy,

In Public Cloud duplicate prevention for Supplier/Customer is essentially Business Partner (BP) duplicate prevention because Supplier/Customer are BP roles. For India GSTIN the right lever is Tax Number Category duplicate check + message control

Point 1.

In CBC:

  1. Open 102415(Maintain Tax Number Categories)
  2. Find the India GSTIN tax category and set Check = On
  3. Save

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2886187

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3673415

Point 2.

By default the duplicate tax number message is typically an information message and depending on the Fiori app it may not stop the save and in some cases may not be shown as you expect. SAP approach in Public Cloud is to adjust the message control for:

  • Application Area: BUPA_TAX

In CBC:

  1. Open 103601(Change Message Control for Duplicate Tax Numbers)
  2. Maintain BUPA_TAX
  3. Set severity to Error to prevent save or Warning to allow with warning

This is the standard way in Public Cloud to switch GST/VAT duplicate tax number handling from info to error

More details below from SAP Community and SAP Notes:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/how-to-change-duplicate-tax-number-category-from-an-info-message-to-an/qaq-p/12301326

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3480717

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3563141

Point 3.

If you also want duplicate detection based on Name + Address, not just GSTIN use the 100274(Configure Matching and Duplicate Check) in CBC

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/f86dc2eb1f8b48c880a7607213104b27/cea95b5830dba007e10000000a441470.html

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3612988

Point 4.

If you need GSTIN + Name + Address must be unique (hard-stop) you‚Äôll typically need an extension/validation on save. In Public Cloud you can read BP tax numbers via CDS View to implement a custom validation logic by Badi in Custom Logic app

More details below from SAP Help and SAP Note:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/2797772

https://fioriappslibrary.hana.ondemand.com/sap/fix/externalViewer/#/detail/Apps('F6957')/S35

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/3aa57e5b9a9f46218ef8cc38d703c8f4.html

Best Regards,

Dawid
